list_page_teaser: This gallery contains spiritual portraits of my immediate family.  Click to learn more!
description_html: These are spiritual portraits of my immediate family.
story_html: Note that I am the only Introvert in the bunch! I always felt rather like the black sheep of the family, but would not be surprised if other family members felt the same way at times.

image_list.title: Jeanne S.
image_list.subtitle_html: My Mom
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: My Mom grew up in Iowa with her younger brother Tom.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Green in this spiritual portrait represents Jeanne's dominant trait, her rationality.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  Note that her preference is very slight (53%) when compared to my Dad's personality.
image_list.explain_aux: The Blue in this spiritual portrait represents Jeanne's auxiliary trait, her idealism.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  Note that her preference is very slight (53%) when compared to my Dad's personality.
image_list.story_html_intro: My Mom got her undergraduate degree from St. Olaf College. Around that time she met my father and ....
image_list.story_html:
My Mom got her undergraduate degree from St. Olaf College. Around that time she met my father and they married in the early 1950s.

After their marriage ended, she worked her way through Graduate School in Richmond, Virginia, and earned a Master's degree in Psychiatric Nursing. She then started working at St. Mary's Hospital as a Psychiatric Nurse.

My parents' divorce was very acrimonious. Eventually they cut off all communication with each other, completely and entirely. Frustration with their behavior during this time certainly led to my interest in psychology — and ultimately to the creation of this site.

Since getting them to answer the questionnaire, I wonder sometimes whether the divorce may have had something to do with their personality types being so similar? Certainly there were many factors at work with all this; moreover, it's best to try to just move on.

My Mom remarried, and I was able to get my step-dad to take the quiz. He turned out to be an ESTJ.

She and my step-dad were happier together than my parents were. Based on this, I am tempted to theorize that relationships work better when there's only one idealist (i.e., iNtuitive type).

When I told her Dad came out as Extraverted, she laughed and exclaimed, Your father is NOT Extraverted! It is obvious they had very serious communication problems!

My mom died in December of 2000. Although I miss her, I have always felt it was good that she did not witness 9/11, because those sorts of things always affected her greatly.

Despite the fact her profile came out as more logical/Green/Thinking type, she could be quite emotional at times. I attribute much of this to the fact she spent many years doing shift work. Having worked some graveyard shifts when I was first starting out, I know from first-hand experience it can be hard on a person.

It may sound strange, but I am glad to have this image to remember her by!

image_list.title: Homer H.
image_list.subtitle_html: My Dad
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: My Dad grew up in Baltimore with two younger brothers, Richard (Dick) and Victor.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Blue in this spiritual portrait represents Homer's dominant trait, his idealism.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  Note that this preference is stronger (over 60%) in his personality than it is in my Mom's personality.
image_list.explain_aux: The Green in this spiritual portrait represents Homer's auxiliary trait, his rationality.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  Note that this preference is stronger (over 60%) in his personality than it is in my Mom's personality.
image_list.story_html_intro: My Dad got his Ph.D. in Chemistry from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill (UNC). Around this time he met my mother and they ....
image_list.story_html:
My Dad got his Ph.D. in Chemistry from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill (UNC). Around this time he met my mother and they married in the early 1950s.

While we lived in Richmond, Virginia, he worked for many years at Texaco and then later at Phillip Morris — in both jobs as a Research Chemist.

My parents' divorce was very acrimonious. Eventually they cut off all communication with each other, completely and entirely. Frustration with their behavior during this time certainly led to my interest in psychology — and ultimately to the creation of this site.

Since getting them to answer the questionnaire, I wonder sometimes whether the divorce may have had something to do with their personality types being so similar? Certainly there were many factors at work with all this; moreover, it's best to try to just move on.

My Dad remarried, but my step-mom refused to take the quiz. In all the years I have been doing this, I cannot remember meeting anyone else who refused to answer the questionnaire. I suspect she was an ESTJ or an ESFJ, but there's no way to know for sure.

He and my step-mom were happier together than my parents were. Based on this, I am tempted to theorize that relationships work better when there's only one idealist (i.e., iNtuitive type).

My dad and I have fallen out of touch over the years. It may sound strange, but I am glad to have this image to remember him by!

image_list.title: Tom H.
image_list.subtitle_html: Oldest Son and Creator of This Site
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: I grew up in Richmond, Virginia and now live in Denver, Colorado.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Red in this spiritual portrait represents Tom's dominant trait, his compassion.  In Introverts, the dominant trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long horizontal line to represent this.  Tom demonstrates this in the great deal of care he puts into creating and sharing spiritual portraits on this site.
image_list.explain_aux: The Blue in this spiritual portrait represents Tom's auxiliary trait, his idealism.  In Introverts, the auxiliary trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a vertical line to represent this, because it is more evident than the dominant function.  Tom demonstrates this in the way he is comfortable dealing with abstractions while creating and sharing spiritual portraits on this site.
image_list.story_html:
Growing up in Richmond, Virginia in the 1960s meant watching assassinations, riots and a war on TV, listening to The Beatles and all the others, and watching too many musicians die of overdoses and the like. We could drink 3.2 beer on our 18th birthday, whoo-hoo!

With that youthful feeling of immortality combined with the impending doom of the Cold War hanging over our heads, it was a good time to smoke cigarettes. In Richmond in those days, they were 25 cents a pack. Also there were friends, beer and The Grateful Dead, and work and school.

My Dad offered to help me with school, and I accepted it for the first year or so. But by then they were divorcing and I decided to pay my own way through it. My idealism certainly played a factor in this decision.

My parents' divorce was very acrimonious. Eventually they cut off all communication with each other, completely and entirely. The divorce was one thing, but that sort of ongoing hostility really made things quite difficult.

Of course, I focused on school, work, and having fun with friends. And as far as making lemonade when given lemons is concerned, it's safe to say that frustration with their behavior during this time certainly led to my interest in psychology — and ultimately to the creation of this site.

Since getting them to answer the questionnaire, I wonder sometimes whether the divorce may have had something to do with their personality types being so similar? Certainly there were many factors at work with all this; moreover, it's best to try to just move on.

So I worked my way through school, sometimes at part-time jobs, and sometimes at full-time jobs. During this time, I had full-time jobs at Overnite Transportation, The City of Richmond VA, and The Bank of Virginia.

Working every day, it took awhile, but eventually I earned my B.S. in Math (Computer Science) and a Masters of Interdisciplinary Studies from Virginia Commonwealth University (VCU).

After getting my B.S. in Math, I had to take a lot of additional courses in Art just to get accepted into the prestigious — at that time — Interdisciplinary program. (VCU no longer offers that degree.) Fortunately I love learning about Art and especially Art History!

It wound up taking me seventeen years — from 1972 through 1989 — to finish the Masters Degree, but I had quit for four years (so it was really only thirteen years) and changed my major a few times.

Moreover I did it My Way, and have no regrets — except maybe for the stupid tobacco habit. Although I spent much of the time working, I loved going to school — and continue to love learning to this day!

I eventually quit the ciggies in 2002, and only wish I'd quit sooner. But that story is for another day.

As the creator of this site, I have a separate gallery that contains multiple self-portraits, along with a story for each one.

You can see these images and read the stories in the gallery of self-portraits on this site.

image_list.title: Marti H.
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Marti grew up in Richmond, Virginia and continues to live there now.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Blue in this spiritual portrait represents Marti's dominant trait, her idealism.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.
image_list.explain_aux: The Red in this spiritual portrait represents Marti's auxiliary trait, her passion.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  Marti demonstrates this trait by the way she loves to play music.
image_list.story_html:
Marti's passion is playing music. She frequents open mic nights in Richmond and posts songs online.

I will share more information as it becomes available.

image_list.title: Matt H.
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Matt grew up in Richmond, Virginia and now lives in Charlottesville.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Blue in this spiritual portrait represents Matt's dominant trait, his rationality.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.
image_list.explain_aux: The Red in this spiritual portrait represents Matt's auxiliary trait, his compassion.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  He demonstrates this trait in the way he cares deeply for his wife and their children.
image_list.story_html:
Matt is happily married with a wife and three children.

I will share more information as it becomes available.
